# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Data

df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)

In Julia, you can solve this problem using the `Year` and `Month` functions from DataFrames.jl package to extract year and month from DateTime type, then convert them into strings and finally concatenate them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”. 

Here's the code:

```julia
using DataFrames

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = string.([Year(x) for x in df.dt]) * string.(["$(Month(x))" for x in df.dt]) |> 
        map(x -> parse(Int64, x), Int)
end

df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)
```

This will add a new column `ym` in your DataFrame with the desired format. The function `add_yearmonth()` converts each datetime to an integer of the form "yyyyMM". For example, for DateTime(2020, 5, 24), it would be 2020505. Note that it will treat the month as zero-padded two digits number (e.g., January would be written as "01", February as "02" etc.), which aligns with your requirement in the task to represent month as a two digit number.
